newsitem.title: TAJIKISTAN: Fighting rocks part of Tajik capital-witnesses.
newsitem.headline: Fighting rocks part of Tajik capital-witnesses.

text.p: Clashes broke out between two rival armed groups in a northern district of the Tajik capital Dushanbe on Saturday, witnesses said.

A Reuter correspondent was turned back from the area of fighting by police but said he heard small arms fire and an explosion. Tajikistan, a former Soviet republic, is trying to emerge from a four-year civil war following a peace accord.

Yakub Salimov, a tax official and a nominally pro-government commander, said by telephone the fighting involved his own armed group and men from an elite unit of Interior Ministry troops led by a commander called Sufrob Kasimov.
"They are shooting here but I have not heard of any casualties so far," he told Reuters.
Tajik military sources said the fighting was linked to a vendetta between local armed groups but there was no official reaction to the fighting.

The Tajik government and armed Islamist guerrillas signed a peace agreement in June to end the civil war but a kaleidescopic array of armed bands threaten stability in the country of 5.7 million people bordering Afghanistan and China.
